title: How to Prepare Romanesco

steps.headline: Break the leaves off the bottom of the romanesco head.
steps.description: Turn the romanesco upside down so you can see where the thick leaves connect to the stem. Grab the base of the leaf, and slowly pull it up until it snaps off. Continue removing all of the leaves around the stem since they aren’t as flavorful as the florets. If you have trouble breaking the leaves off of the romanesco head, use a sharp chef’s knife to cut them off.

steps.headline: Cut the head of romanesco into quarters.
steps.description: Set the base of the romanesco head on your cutting board so the pointed end faces up. Start the blade of your chef’s knife on top of the romanesco and push it straight down through the stem to split it in half. Then lay each half flat on the cut side and slice vertically through them again so you have 4 wedge-shaped pieces that are easier to work with.You can leave the romanesco in wedges if you want. Romanesco wedges are great for roasting.

steps.headline: Slice along the stem to remove the florets.
steps.description: Stand the romanesco up so the base of the stem is against your cutting board. Carefully guide your knife through the romanesco so the blade presses against the side of the stem. Stay as close to the stem as possible so you don’t break any of the florets. Continue cutting the rest of the wedges and throw away the stems.Work slowly and keep your fingers away from the blade so you don’t accidentally cut yourself while you’re working.Variation: You may also break the florets off of the stem by hand if it’s easier for you. Grab the base of the floret and bend it toward the bottom of the wedge until it snaps off the stem.

steps.headline: Break down larger pieces so the romanesco cooks evenly.
steps.description: Compare the sizes of each floret to find which pieces are the largest and smallest. Slice the larger florets in half along their stems until they’re similar in size to the smallest pieces. That way, the florets will all cook at the same rate so they don’t get overdone.If you keep the romanesco pieces differently sized, the larger pieces may still be raw in the middle while the smaller ones are completely cooked through.

steps.headline: Rinse and dry the romanesco florets to clean them.
steps.description: Put the romanesco pieces in a colander and run them underneath cold water from your sink. Shake the colander so the water flows over all of the pieces evenly. Pat the pieces dry with a paper towel so they aren’t wet when you start cooking them.Avoid using warm or hot water to rinse the romanesco since you could soften them and ruin their texture.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 425 °F (218 °C).
steps.description: Place one of the racks inside your oven in the middle position so the romanesco cooks through evenly without getting burnt. Set your oven to bake at 425 °F (218 °C) and let it warm up completely before you start cooking.

steps.headline: Toss the romanesco pieces in olive oil, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Put the romanesco in a large bowl and drizzle 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil over them. Stir the romanesco with a spoon or mix it by hand so the oil coats all of the pieces. Sprinkle in pinches of salt and pepper until you’re happy with the flavor and continue tossing the romanesco until you’ve spread out the seasoning.Try adding garlic powder or paprika to the romanesco if you want to add more flavor. Be careful while tossing the romanesco since the florets may break apart.

steps.headline: Put the romanesco on a baking tray in the oven for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Spread the romanesco evenly in a single layer on a rimmed baking tray. It’s okay if the pieces touch, but don’t let them overlap, or else they may not cook as evenly.If you want to try different seasonings, split the romanesco between 2 different trays.Tip: Line the baking tray with aluminum foil for easy cleanup. When you’re finished cooking, remove the aluminum foil and throw it away so you don’t have to wash the tray.

steps.headline: Put the romanesco in the oven for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Set the baking tray on the center rack of your oven and allow the romanesco to cook for at least 10 minutes. Keep the oven door closed while you cook the romanesco, or else the heat will escape and it will take longer to roast.

steps.headline: Flip the florets with a spatula and cook them for another 5–10 minutes.
steps.description: Quickly pull the tray out from the oven and set it on your stove. Use your spatula to flip the pieces over and mix them around to ensure you cook both sides. Place the tray back in your oven and let the romanesco continue cooking for 5–10 minutes until the ends look golden-brown.Test a small piece of the romanesco when you take it out of the oven to see if it feels tender.

steps.headline: Serve the romanesco while it’s still hot.
steps.description: Use the romanesco as a side dish with any meal if you want a healthy vegetable. Otherwise, try mixing the romanesco with rice, quinoa, or pasta to make it stand out in an entree. Eat the romanesco right away since it may cool off quickly.Store any leftover romanesco in an airtight container for 7–10 days in your fridge. You can reheat the leftovers in your microwave or oven.

steps.headline: Bring a pot of water to a boil.
steps.description: Choose a pot that’s large enough to hold all of your romanesco and fill it ¾-full with water. Put the pot on your stove over high heat until it comes to a rolling boil. Add a pinch of salt to the water if you want to season it.

steps.headline: Boil the romanesco for 2–3 minutes.
steps.description: Place the romanesco florets in the pot and allow the water to heat up again. Stir the romanesco in the pot for 2–3 minutes so the pieces get more tender before removing them from heat.If you try to saute the romanesco without boiling them first, it could still be raw in the middle and have an inconsistent texture.

steps.headline: Dunk the florets in a bowl of cold water for 10 seconds.
steps.description: Fill a large bowl with cold water and scoop the romanesco into it. Allow the romanesco to soak for about 10 seconds so the pieces cool down and stop cooking.If you don’t soak the romanesco in cold water, they will have a mushy texture and get overcooked when you try to saute it.

steps.headline: Pat the romanesco dry with a paper towel.
steps.description: Scoop the florets out of the cold water with a slotted spoon and set them on a piece of paper towel. Allow them to drip dry before lightly patting them with another piece of paper towel so they aren’t wet when you cook them.You can also let the romanesco air-dry completely.

steps.headline: Saute butter and garlic in a skillet over medium heat.
steps.description: Put 2 tablespoons (28.4 g) of butter in a skillet and turn it onto medium heat. Let the butter melt, and tilt the pan so the butter coats it evenly. Add 2 cloves of minced garlic and let them cook until they’re golden-brownVariation: If you don’t want to use butter, you can also use 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of any other cooking oil.

steps.headline: Add the romanesco and cook it for 5–6 minutes.
steps.description: Stir the romanesco and garlic occasionally to combine the flavors and ensure the pieces don’t overcook. Keep the romanesco in the pan for 5–6 minutes, or until you can easily poke through the pieces with a fork.The ends of the florets will turn golden-brown as you cook them.

steps.headline: Serve the romanesco while it’s still hot.
steps.description: Scoop the romanesco out of the pan and put it into a serving dish. Enjoy the romanesco as a healthy side dish with your meal, or combine it with rice or quinoa if you want to incorporate it into your entree.Keep leftover pieces in a resealable bag or container for 7–10 days in your fridge.

steps.headline: Bring a pot with 1 in (2.5 cm) of water to a simmer.
steps.description: Choose a pot that has a lid and is large enough to fit all of the romanesco florets. Add 1 inch (2.5 cm) of water to the pot and put it on your stove over medium heat. Keep heating the water until it starts to bubble. You can also use a wide skillet or pan if you don’t have a pot that’s deep enough for all of your romanesco.

steps.headline: Put the romanesco florets in the pot.
steps.description: Spread the romanesco as evenly as you can in the pot so each piece is partially submerged. Be careful not to break the florets any smaller, or else they may not cook evenly.Variation: You can also put the romanesco inside of a steamer basket and place it on top of the pot if you don’t want to put the florets directly in the water.

steps.headline: Cover the pot with a lid.
steps.description: Immediately put a lid on the pot to trap the steam inside so the florets cook faster. Make sure the lid fits tightly against the lip of the pot. Keep the lid on at all times to prevent steam from escaping.

steps.headline: Cook the romanesco for 15 minutes or until they’re tender.
steps.description: Leave the pot over medium-low heat so it maintains a simmer. Avoid removing the lid since it lets the steam escape and could affect how long it takes for your romanesco to cook. After 15 minutes, see if you can easily stab into one of the florets with a fork, which means they’re cooked through and tender.The romanesco will also change to a lighter green color as they cook so you can easily tell when they’re finished cooking.

steps.headline: Drain the romanesco into a colander.
steps.description: Set a colander in your sink and pour the romanesco into it so the water drains out. Shake the colander to remove any excess water that’s still stuck between the pieces.If you don’t have a colander, hold the lid against the lip of the pot and slowly pour the water into your sink. Keep the lid in place so the romanesco doesn’t fall out.

steps.headline: Season the romanesco before serving it.
steps.description: Return the florets to the pot and sprinkle salt and pepper on them. Stir the seasoning into the romanesco until it’s thoroughly mixed before serving them. You can keep cooked romanesco in your fridge for up to 10 days if you store it in a resealable bag or container.

sentences: Cutting the Florets Break the leaves off the bottom of the romanesco head.
Turn the romanesco upside down so you can see where the thick leaves connect to the stem.
Grab the base of the leaf, and slowly pull it up until it snaps off.
Continue removing all of the leaves around the stem since they aren’t as flavorful as the florets.
If you have trouble breaking the leaves off of the romanesco head, use a sharp chef’s knife to cut them off.
Cut the head of romanesco into quarters.
Set the base of the romanesco head on your cutting board so the pointed end faces up.
Start the blade of your chef’s knife on top of the romanesco and push it straight down through the stem to split it in half.
Then lay each half flat on the cut side and slice vertically through them again so you have 4 wedge-shaped pieces that are easier to work with.You can leave the romanesco in wedges if you want.
Romanesco wedges are great for roasting.
Slice along the stem to remove the florets.
Stand the romanesco up so the base of the stem is against your cutting board.
Carefully guide your knife through the romanesco so the blade presses against the side of the stem.
Stay as close to the stem as possible so you don’t break any of the florets.

Continue cutting the rest of the wedges and throw away the stems.Work slowly and keep your fingers away from the blade so you don’t accidentally cut yourself while you’re working.Variation: You may also break the florets off of the stem by hand if it’s easier for you.
Grab the base of the floret and bend it toward the bottom of the wedge until it snaps off the stem.
Break down larger pieces so the romanesco cooks evenly.
Compare the sizes of each floret to find which pieces are the largest and smallest.
Slice the larger florets in half along their stems until they’re similar in size to the smallest pieces.

That way, the florets will all cook at the same rate so they don’t get overdone.If you keep the romanesco pieces differently sized, the larger pieces may still be raw in the middle while the smaller ones are completely cooked through.
Rinse and dry the romanesco florets to clean them.
Put the romanesco pieces in a colander and run them underneath cold water from your sink.
Shake the colander so the water flows over all of the pieces evenly.
Pat the pieces dry with a paper towel so they aren’t wet when you start cooking them.Avoid using warm or hot water to rinse the romanesco since you could soften them and ruin their texture.
Simple Roasted Romanesco Preheat your oven to 425 °F (218 °C).
Place one of the racks inside your oven in the middle position so the romanesco cooks through evenly without getting burnt.
Set your oven to bake at 425 °F (218 °C) and let it warm up completely before you start cooking.
Toss the romanesco pieces in olive oil, salt, and pepper.
Put the romanesco in a large bowl and drizzle 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil over them.
Stir the romanesco with a spoon or mix it by hand so the oil coats all of the pieces.

Sprinkle in pinches of salt and pepper until you’re happy with the flavor and continue tossing the romanesco until you’ve spread out the seasoning.Try adding garlic powder or paprika to the romanesco if you want to add more flavor.
Be careful while tossing the romanesco since the florets may break apart.
Put the romanesco on a baking tray in the oven for 10 minutes.
Spread the romanesco evenly in a single layer on a rimmed baking tray.

It’s okay if the pieces touch, but don’t let them overlap, or else they may not cook as evenly.If you want to try different seasonings, split the romanesco between 2 different trays.Tip: Line the baking tray with aluminum foil for easy cleanup.
When you’re finished cooking, remove the aluminum foil and throw it away so you don’t have to wash the tray.
Put the romanesco in the oven for 10 minutes.
Set the baking tray on the center rack of your oven and allow the romanesco to cook for at least 10 minutes.
Keep the oven door closed while you cook the romanesco, or else the heat will escape and it will take longer to roast.
Flip the florets with a spatula and cook them for another 5–10 minutes.
Quickly pull the tray out from the oven and set it on your stove.
Use your spatula to flip the pieces over and mix them around to ensure you cook both sides.

Place the tray back in your oven and let the romanesco continue cooking for 5–10 minutes until the ends look golden-brown.Test a small piece of the romanesco when you take it out of the oven to see if it feels tender.
Serve the romanesco while it’s still hot.
Use the romanesco as a side dish with any meal if you want a healthy vegetable.
Otherwise, try mixing the romanesco with rice, quinoa, or pasta to make it stand out in an entree.
Eat the romanesco right away since it may cool off quickly.Store any leftover romanesco in an airtight container for 7–10 days in your fridge.
You can reheat the leftovers in your microwave or oven.
Sauteed Romanesco with Garlic Bring a pot of water to a boil.
Choose a pot that’s large enough to hold all of your romanesco and fill it ¾-full with water.
Put the pot on your stove over high heat until it comes to a rolling boil.
Add a pinch of salt to the water if you want to season it.
Boil the romanesco for 2–3 minutes.
Place the romanesco florets in the pot and allow the water to heat up again.

Stir the romanesco in the pot for 2–3 minutes so the pieces get more tender before removing them from heat.If you try to saute the romanesco without boiling them first, it could still be raw in the middle and have an inconsistent texture.
Dunk the florets in a bowl of cold water for 10 seconds.
Fill a large bowl with cold water and scoop the romanesco into it.

Allow the romanesco to soak for about 10 seconds so the pieces cool down and stop cooking.If you don’t soak the romanesco in cold water, they will have a mushy texture and get overcooked when you try to saute it.
Pat the romanesco dry with a paper towel.
Scoop the florets out of the cold water with a slotted spoon and set them on a piece of paper towel.
Allow them to drip dry before lightly patting them with another piece of paper towel so they aren’t wet when you cook them.You can also let the romanesco air-dry completely.
Saute butter and garlic in a skillet over medium heat.
Put 2 tablespoons (28.4 g) of butter in a skillet and turn it onto medium heat.
Let the butter melt, and tilt the pan so the butter coats it evenly.
Add 2 cloves of minced garlic and let them cook until they’re golden-brownVariation: If you don’t want to use butter, you can also use 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of any other cooking oil.
Add the romanesco and cook it for 5–6 minutes.
Stir the romanesco and garlic occasionally to combine the flavors and ensure the pieces don’t overcook.
Keep the romanesco in the pan for 5–6 minutes, or until you can easily poke through the pieces with a fork.The ends of the florets will turn golden-brown as you cook them.
Serve the romanesco while it’s still hot.
Scoop the romanesco out of the pan and put it into a serving dish.

Enjoy the romanesco as a healthy side dish with your meal, or combine it with rice or quinoa if you want to incorporate it into your entree.Keep leftover pieces in a resealable bag or container for 7–10 days in your fridge.
Steamed Romanesco Bring a pot with 1 in (2.5 cm) of water to a simmer.
Choose a pot that has a lid and is large enough to fit all of the romanesco florets.
Add 1 inch (2.5 cm) of water to the pot and put it on your stove over medium heat.
Keep heating the water until it starts to bubble.
You can also use a wide skillet or pan if you don’t have a pot that’s deep enough for all of your romanesco.
Put the romanesco florets in the pot.
Spread the romanesco as evenly as you can in the pot so each piece is partially submerged.

Be careful not to break the florets any smaller, or else they may not cook evenly.Variation: You can also put the romanesco inside of a steamer basket and place it on top of the pot if you don’t want to put the florets directly in the water.
Cover the pot with a lid.
Immediately put a lid on the pot to trap the steam inside so the florets cook faster.
Make sure the lid fits tightly against the lip of the pot.
Keep the lid on at all times to prevent steam from escaping.
Cook the romanesco for 15 minutes or until they’re tender.
Leave the pot over medium-low heat so it maintains a simmer.
Avoid removing the lid since it lets the steam escape and could affect how long it takes for your romanesco to cook.

After 15 minutes, see if you can easily stab into one of the florets with a fork, which means they’re cooked through and tender.The romanesco will also change to a lighter green color as they cook so you can easily tell when they’re finished cooking.
Drain the romanesco into a colander.
Set a colander in your sink and pour the romanesco into it so the water drains out.
Shake the colander to remove any excess water that’s still stuck between the pieces.If you don’t have a colander, hold the lid against the lip of the pot and slowly pour the water into your sink.
Keep the lid in place so the romanesco doesn’t fall out.
Season the romanesco before serving it.
Return the florets to the pot and sprinkle salt and pepper on them.
Stir the seasoning into the romanesco until it’s thoroughly mixed before serving them.
You can keep cooked romanesco in your fridge for up to 10 days if you store it in a resealable bag or container.
